unit: Unit 9 | Inference for Quantitative Data: Slopes
title: Regression Computer Output
question_text:
Suppose bivariate data was collected on NFL quarterbacksâ€™ fantasy football points during the current year ($Y$) compared to the fantasy points of the year before ($X$).
Twenty quarterbacks were selected for this data. Summary data is as follows for the linear equation $y = a+bx$.
$b = 0.6776$ $a = 0.2305$ ${ SE }_{ b }= 0.08807$*
A $99\%$ linear regression $T$-interval

choices.text: Captures $1$, which fails to give evidence of any positive correlation between current year and previous year fantasy points.
Does not capture $0$, failing to give evidence of a positive linear relationship.
Does not capture $1$, failing to give evidence of any positive linear correlation between current year and previous year fantasy points.
Captures $0$, failing to give evidence of a positive linear relationship.
Is entirely above $0$, giving evidence of a positive linear relationship.

solution:
A sample size of $n = 20$ gives $18$ degrees of freedom. With bivariate data, degrees of freedom is calculated by $n - 2$, where $n$ represents the number or ordered pairs.

The problem asks for a $99\%$ confidence interval. Linear Regression uses the $T$ distribution, so using the $T$ table, find where $99\%$ confidence meets $18$ degrees of freedom to find a critical $t^*$ value of $2.878$.

The standard error of the slope, also known as $SE_b$, represents how far the typical sample slope will be from the unknown population slope. This is given in the problem, and also will be used in the formula.

A $99\%$ confidence interval goes from $0.424$ to $0.931$ using the equation below:

$$\text{Interval}= \text{Sample Slope} \pm t \times ({ SE }_{ b})$$

$$\text{Interval}= 0.6776 \pm 2.878(0.08807)$$

This interval hopes to estimate the unknown population slope; a population slope of zero would represent no linear relationship, a population slope below zero would represent a negative linear relationship, and a population slope above zero would represent a positive linear relationship.

Since the entire interval (that gives plausible values of the true unknown population slope) is above zero, we have evidence of a positive linear relationship.

Thus, the correct answer is Choice 'E'.
